Table Descriptions.Description: Issues and Mitigating Best Practices for Reproducibility Problems in AI/ML
Issues and mitigating best practices for reproducibility in AI/ML
Row Labels: Weights are so different that model predictions are very different.
Works for me, but not for you

Page Summaries: This page presents information about the 'Machine Learning Operations for Accelerator Control' led by Tia Miceli from the Accelerator AI/ML Group, Accelerator Controls Department at FNAL, and includes details about an upcoming EPICS Collaboration Meeting scheduled for 24-28 April 2023.

This page highlights the necessity for sustainable practices in developing, deploying, monitoring, and managing machine learning applications for accelerators. It points out challenges such as the loss of key personnel, issues with reproducibility in deep learning, and life-cycle handling, especially in spontaneous scenarios.

The slide emphasizes the importance of sustainable practices in the development, deployment, monitoring, and servicing of machine learning applications, particularly for accelerators. Key issues addressed include the departure of knowledgeable individuals, the reproducibility problem in deep learning, and the need to automate common updates to ensure continued efficacy and reliable operation.

This page addresses reproducibility issues in AI/ML, including typical and tricky problems, alongside best practices to mitigate them. The table on the page highlights different levels of issues and the corresponding strategies for handling them.

The page highlights the reproducibility problem in AI/ML where the same model weights cannot be reproduced by different individuals. It outlines typical and tricky issues and provides best practices to mitigate these problems, such as version controlling the model and environment.

This page discusses the potential challenges of deploying an AI controller model and highlights the importance of MLOps (Machine Learning Operations) in addressing issues such as data drift, performance monitoring, and automated retraining.

This page discusses the requirements for deploying an AI/ML capability for operations, emphasizing the need for engineering and stewardship in aspects such as live-streaming data ingestion, model inference serving, and prediction streaming.
This page presents a workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) in accelerator control, detailing the stages from data management to system operations.

This page contains a diagram detailing the workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) for accelerator control. It breaks down the process into data management, AI/ML modeling, operations development, and system operations.

This page illustrates the workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) in accelerator control. The workflow is divided into four main phases: Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations. Specific tasks related to data management are listed, such as standardized data logging and filtering, standardized format, interface for ML Engineer's data filter, and dataset management system including versioning and metadata tracking.

This page outlines the workflow for machine learning operations (MLOps) in accelerator control. It includes stages for data management, AI/ML modeling, operations development, and system operations. Specific components like standardized acceleration data logger and filter, dataset management system, and the roles of these components in the workflow are described.

This page provides a visual representation of the workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps). It includes stages for Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations. The page also outlines the use of common tools and systems for model development and data management, emphasizing standardized formats and interfaces for machine learning engineers.

This page outlines the workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) in accelerator control, featuring steps like data management, AI/ML modeling, operations development, and system operations. It highlights the standardized tools and processes used, including datasets management systems, data logging, filtering, and common tools for model development.

This page illustrates the workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) including detailed steps for data management, AI/ML modeling, operations development, and system operations. It highlights the use of standardized tools and interfaces for managing data and models.

The page provides a detailed workflow for machine learning operations (MLOps) in accelerator control. It includes stages of Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, and Operations Development along with standardized tools and systems required for efficient operations.

This page presents a visual representation of the workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps). It outlines the cycle between Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, and Operations Development, including steps like data collection, model training, and deployment. Additionally, it highlights the use of common tools like the Model Development System and interfaces for ML engineers.

The page presents a workflow for machine learning operations (MLOps) for accelerator control, detailing steps such as Data Management, AI / ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations. Additional notes and interfaces for ML Engineers are provided.

This page illustrates and summarizes the workflow for Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) in accelerator control. It comprises sections on Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations, with detailed points on standardization, tools, interfaces, and system setup.

The page provides an overview of the workflow for MLOps (Machine Learning Operations) within accelerator control. It details stages including Data Management, AI/ML Modeling, Operations Development, and System Operations, highlighting processes such as data collection, model training, deployment, and monitoring, as well as various tools and interfaces used at each stage.

This page discusses the expansion of DevOps into MLOps (Machine Learning Operations). It highlights key elements of MLOps, including integration and streamlining of software development and deployment, agile software development practices, and Continuous Integration/Continuous Delivery (CI/CD). It also mentions that DevOps has roots in Lean Manufacturing practices.

This page outlines the necessary infrastructure for managing MLOps in accelerator controls, focusing on different aspects such as Data Management, Model Development, Operations Development, and System Operations. It provides a brief overview of the tools and processes involved in each area, highlighting the importance of advanced version control, shared compute resources, and proper server specifications.

This page discusses Fermilab's efforts to develop MLOps for their accelerator controls. It covers formalizing integration requirements, collaborating with other laboratories like SLAC, CERN, and BNL, and developing open-source toolsets on a Kubernetes cluster. The image provides a visual representation of the infrastructure needed for accelerator controls MLOps, detailing components such as data management, model development, operational development, and system operations.

This page discusses the design of MLOps infrastructure by the Fermilab Accelerator Controls AI/ML Group. It seeks input on effective and ineffective workflows, showcasing the group's lead, Tia Miceli.

This page is an announcement for the 4th ICFA Beam Dynamics Mini-Workshop focusing on Machine Learning Applications for Particle Accelerators. The event will take place from 5th to 8th of March 2024 in Gyeongju, Republic of Korea, organized by the Pohang Accelerator Laboratory and POSTECH.
